original: The theoretical maximum yield of ATP through oxidation of one molecule of glucose in glycolysis, citric acid cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation is 38 (assuming 3 molar equivalents of ATP per equivalent NADH and 2 ATP per FADH2).
question: The ________ of ATP through oxidation of one molecule of glucose in glycolysis, citric acid cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation is 38 (assuming 3 molar equivalents of ATP per equivalent NADH and 2 ATP per FADH2).
answered_question: The {{theoretical maximum yield}} of ATP through oxidation of one molecule of glucose in glycolysis, citric acid cycle, and oxidative phosphorylation is 38 (assuming 3 molar equivalents of ATP per equivalent NADH and 2 ATP per FADH2).

original: In eukaryotes, two equivalents of NADH and four equivalents of ATP are generated in glycolysis, which takes place in the cytoplasm.
question: In eukaryotes, two equivalents of ________ and four equivalents of ATP are generated in glycolysis, which takes place in the cytoplasm.
answered_question: In eukaryotes, two equivalents of {{NADH}} and four equivalents of ATP are generated in glycolysis, which takes place in the cytoplasm.

original: Transport of two of these equivalents of NADH into the mitochondria consumes two equivalents of ATP, thus reducing the net production of ATP to 36.
question: Transport of ________ of these equivalents of NADH into the mitochondria consumes two equivalents of ATP, thus reducing the net production of ATP to 36.
answered_question: Transport of {{two}} of these equivalents of NADH into the mitochondria consumes two equivalents of ATP, thus reducing the net production of ATP to 36.

original: Furthermore, inefficiencies in oxidative phosphorylation due to leakage of protons across the mitochondrial membrane and slippage of the ATP synthase/proton pump commonly reduces the ATP yield from NADH and FADH2 to less than the theoretical maximum yield.
question: Furthermore, inefficiencies in ________ to leakage of protons across the mitochondrial membrane and slippage of the ATP synthase/proton pump commonly reduces the ATP yield from NADH and FADH2 to less than the theoretical maximum yield.
answered_question: Furthermore, inefficiencies in {{oxidative phosphorylation due}} to leakage of protons across the mitochondrial membrane and slippage of the ATP synthase/proton pump commonly reduces the ATP yield from NADH and FADH2 to less than the theoretical maximum yield.

original: The observed yields are, therefore, closer to ~2.5 ATP per NADH and ~1.5 ATP per FADH2, further reducing the total net production of ATP to approximately 30.
question: The observed yields are, therefore, closer to ~2.5 ATP per NADH and ~1.5 ATP per FADH2, further reducing the ________ of ATP to approximately 30.
answered_question: The observed yields are, therefore, closer to ~2.5 ATP per NADH and ~1.5 ATP per FADH2, further reducing the {{total net production}} of ATP to approximately 30.

original: An assessment of the total ATP yield with newly revised proton-to-ATP ratios provides an estimate of 29.85 ATP per glucose molecule.
question: An assessment of the ________ with newly revised proton-to-ATP ratios provides an estimate of 29.85 ATP per glucose molecule.
answered_question: An assessment of the {{total ATP yield}} with newly revised proton-to-ATP ratios provides an estimate of 29.85 ATP per glucose molecule.
